div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of newspaper clipping, [September 30, 1900] (See Spanish original)
div1.p:
The news of the death of Doctor
Lazear occurred on the night of the 23 of
September, in the American Camp
near the "Quemados de Marianao",
has made a profound and painful impression
on all those who met the man, from every point
of view, worthy of esteem that
knowingly, as we can well say, has
sacrificed himself through devotion to science to
whose progress he had devoted his life.

Graduate from Johns
Hopkins University, when Dr. Jesse W.
Lazear came to Cuba, in order to study the
causes and methods of propagation of
yellow fever, had a well earned
reputation as a bacteriologist and
expert in the use of the microscope, of
which he gave here repeated tests, since his
microscopic tests of blood have served in order
to be able to correctly diagnose cases of fever
still not characterized. - As a member
of the Society charged with the study
of the prevailing sicknesses in "intertropical"
countries, he dedicated himself assiduously,
and with notable progress,
to research and experiments with
Cuban mosquitos, propagators of
malaria and of other fevers.
Not withstanding the danger to which he certainly
exposed himself, the last four
months of his life, he was at the head
of yellow fever patients, curing them
and helping them with unlimited selflessness;
and so he contracted the terrible sickness
that put an end to his days when he
was not more than 34 years of age.

And to his indisputable merit as
a man of science and as a philanthropist,
he united an exquisite affability that won him
the hearts of all those who dealt with him,
in such a way that he had as many friends as acquaintances.
